audio_caption: The audio clip starts with light, upbeat instrumental music, creating a pleasant atmosphere. A friendly-sounding woman introduces herself as Joe and welcomes listeners back to a discussion about airport security. She briefly mentions a recent trip to Las Vegas and how it led to her having some questions about airport security as someone with a visible disability, and that she wants to share her experiences. In addition, a friend on the trip took some video, and she will show the listeners some visual aid. The clip concludes with the same upbeat background music.

The clip begins with a female speaker encouraging listeners to like the video to increase its reach and YouTube engagement, but assuring them there's no pressure. She then transitions to discussing the TSA and flight security, noting that many see it as a necessary hassle. She reflects on her experiences before her amputation, which included taking off shoes and removing belongings, with one incident involving medication that led to a temporary detention. After mentioning her amputation, the speaker states how things have changed. Throughout the clip, the speaker speaks in an informative and conversational tone, and there is ambient background sound of the indoors.

The clip starts with a female speaker introducing her topic, clarifying that her experience may not be universal and mentioning she'll provide official information. Her tone is conversational and informative. She then poses a hypothetical question about traveling with a prosthetic leg, wondering if security would ask her to remove it. She answers with a no, elaborating that the device is considered part of the person, like someone in a wheelchair shouldn't be asked to stand up. The speaker adds that additional precautions are taken, stating she's been fully searched every time, except once, including being "feeling you up kind of searched". She emphasizes this could be unsettling, especially for someone with trauma, as it involves touching private areas in front of others, calling it "weird" and "uncomfortable".

The audio clip begins with a female speaker describing her experience of being searched, noting that "the vast majority of the time, they will actually search you." Her tone is conversational but slightly uncomfortable as she explains that these searches, though not strip searches, often happen in front of other people. There are several people walking by, and she expresses discomfort with the situation she is describing, "being felt up everywhere," mentioning it is "not my favorite experience."

The clip features a single female speaker who warns, "Something to be aware of is that you can request they do this in private if that's something that you're more comfortable with".  She then shares her personal preference, "I would be less comfortable with that because I don't want to be alone with someone who's touching me." She then continues, "This is a real possibility if you are an amputee going through security and you are wearing a prosthetic." A distinct sound effect is audible, likely from the end of a media editing program.

A female speaker describes how security personnel wipe down various parts of her body with pads to test for "chemicals or anything like that". She mentions the pads are rubbed on her fingers and prosthetic leg, then run through a machine. She clarifies that security still wipes down her prosthetic leg and hands even when they don't fully search her. She describes the pad as "dry" but able to "pick up what they need to pick up on".

The audio clip features a single female speaker advising the listener to budget extra time when going to the airport. She describes her past experiences going through airport security in a wheelchair or with a prosthetic, which took longer to be searched. Although the airport personnel were respectful, she emphasized that these situations take extra time out of everyone's day, and it's difficult to deal with while stressed. The tone is conversational and friendly.

The audio clip begins with a female speaker informing the audience about requesting a wheelchair at an airport. She explains that some airports are large and require a lot of walking, and in that case, someone can bring you from location to location. But one needs to call ahead, as most airports don't let someone push you around. Instead, they have someone assigned to transfer you. Light, upbeat music plays during the gaps in her speech.

The clip starts with a female speaker discussing security protocols for individuals with prosthetic feet, noting the difficulty of removing shoes. She explains that one can inform security personnel about their medical condition. She indicates this is so they can "do the appropriate measures," but that you do not have to take your shoes off.

The audio clip begins with a female speaker describing a travel experience, noting that US and Dublin airports are "mobility-friendly" and accessible. She then discusses airport security measures, explaining that she tries to remain calm and understanding, recognizing that security personnel are following protocol, although the additional screening can be uncomfortable. She emphasizes the importance of mental preparation and that most experiences are respectful and positive, hoping that listeners will have the same experiences. All speech is delivered in a friendly and conversational tone.

The audio clip begins with a female speaker expressing curiosity about experiences with airport security, inviting listeners to share their stories and tips, emphasizing the value of education and anxiety reduction. She then thanks patrons for making the videos possible and encourages interested viewers to explore her Patreon link. She concludes by thanking listeners for their time and expressing affection. A gentle acoustic guitar melody then introduces a soft, folksy song, conveying a positive and optimistic mood. The speaker sings "Have a good from the sky all about it, down the river high tide goes around here, through the whispers of pines, I hear them sing, the more you love the more you live". The recording ends with the lyrics still being sung.
